title: The Vanity of Wealth and Life
shortSummary: Ecclesiastes 6 explores the futility of wealth, long life, and human desires when they are not accompanied by true satisfaction or God's blessing. The chapter highlights the emptiness of earthly gains and the mystery of life’s purpose under the sun, urging readers to seek contentment and wisdom beyond material abundance.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Traditional period of Solomon's reign and authorship

keyCharacters.name: The Preacher (Qoheleth)
keyCharacters.description: The author and speaker of Ecclesiastes who reflects on the meaninglessness of life apart from God.

keyCharacters.name: The Rich Man
keyCharacters.description: A figure representing those who have wealth and honor but lack the power to enjoy their blessings.

keyCharacters.name: The Fool
keyCharacters.description: A contrast to the wise, representing those who lack understanding but may share in life's vanity.

definitions.definition: A key term in Ecclesiastes meaning emptiness, futility, or meaningless, especially in reference to human pursuits without God.
The inner life or personhood of a human being, encompassing desires, emotions, and spiritual life.
A metaphor for a stillborn or prematurely dead child, used here to illustrate a life that never experiences vanity or suffering.
A phrase describing deep frustration or distress of the heart and mind.

outline.heading: The Futility of Wealth Without Enjoyment
outline.description: The Preacher observes the injustice of a man who has all earthly blessings but cannot enjoy them, highlighting the vanity and evil of such a condition.

outline.heading: The Emptiness of Long Life Without Satisfaction
outline.description: Even a man with many children and a long life is deemed worse off than a stillborn if he lacks fulfillment and honor, emphasizing the vanity of life without contentment.

outline.heading: The Insatiable Nature of Human Desire
outline.description: Human labor and appetite are never fully satisfied, and the Preacher contrasts the wise and the fool, concluding that desire's wandering is itself vanity and vexation.

outline.heading: The Limitations of Man and the Increase of Vanity
outline.description: Man cannot contend with the mighty or fully understand what is good for him, and the increase of vanity leaves man no better, underscoring the mystery of life’s purpose.

application: Trust God to grant the ability to enjoy your blessings rather than merely accumulating wealth.
Seek contentment and satisfaction in God rather than in the length of life or the number of offspring.
Guard against insatiable desires that lead to frustration and spiritual emptiness.
Recognize human limitations and submit humbly to God's sovereign wisdom in all things.

keyVerses.text: A man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soul of all that he desireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger eateth it: this is vanity, and it is an evil disease.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the tragic futility of having blessings without the ability to enjoy them, illustrating the emptiness of earthly wealth apart from God's favor.

keyVerses.text: If a man beget an hundred children, and live many years, so that the days of his years be many, and his soul be not filled with good, and also that he have no burial; I say, that an untimely birth is better than he.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches that a long life and many descendants are meaningless without true satisfaction and honor, emphasizing the value of a fulfilled soul.

keyVerses.text: Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire: this is also vanity and vexation of spirit.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns against restless desires and promotes contentment with what is seen and possessed, exposing the spiritual distress caused by unfulfilled longing.

keyVerses.text: For who knoweth what is good for man in this life, all the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores human ignorance about the true good in life and the uncertainty of what follows, calling believers to trust God's wisdom.
